ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a thorough understanding of the basic building blocks of life from a biochemical standpoint, in addition to its applications to medicine.

The course provided a very interesting and helpful overview of key biological concepts, focusing on the broad ideas that are seen in various different processes. We also explored several specific processes as ways of better understanding the general trends and pathways. We also learned how to perform molecular docking, which is super helpful and relevant (in many research situations -- in fact, it became super helpful to me in my summer research).
Basics of biochemistry -- bringing together foundational chemical and biological concepts

A lot of knowledge on the metabolism cycles within the body, as well as a better understanding of the application of many organic chemistry concepts within the context of the body's biological processes.
I learned a lot about the mechanisms of different biological processes

I learned the fundamentals of Biochemistry though this course. These basics are going to be very helpful in my career path, I believe. One thing especially I learned was the process of drug development and alteration. This was especially interesting as I hadn't gotten the oppurtunity before to explore this pharmaceutical of medicine.

I have learned some of the most important concepts for biochemistry- amino acids, protein studies, DNA and RNA molecular structure, fats and carbohydrates, and respiration mechanism under the scope of biochemistry (glycolysis, citric acid cycle, electron transport chain). In addition to the textbook materials, hands-on drug design project really had me engaged fully into the world of biochemistry. As I ran the softwares to simulates and analyze the novel drug, I have found myself immersed in the wonderland of biochemistry and indulged in the sanguine sensation upon promising data from the novel drug I have developed. Asides from course experience, I learned to be able to express my understanding for science more clearly and organized from class participation (answering questions in class or providing some of my thoughts). Moreover, from the drug design project, I have learned the perspiration and diligence are what makes a science project possible.
I learned the basics of biochemistry, such as metabolism, fat synthesis, etc.
I engaged in/talked with my professor more than I have ever done for a STEM course.
Enzymes, Hemoglobin, Metabolism, Protein Structure, Protein analytic techniques.
Basic biochemistry knowledge as well as its applications in pharmacology and chemistry.
Quantitative reasoning skills and test taking skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was wonderfully taught and packed with information. Although it was a bit overwhelming at times (given that we had so much material to cover in such little time), it was a great learning experience.

Strengths -- very interesting material, presented in a clear way with a focus on broad patterns and trends rather than tons and tons of memorization. super relevant skills (ie molecular docking) and cool class project!
Weaknesses -- None!

The course was interesting and fast-paced. The summer nature of the course did restrict the amount of material which could be reasonably covered, and it was unclear how much the reading factored into the course. I think a more concise, focused set of readings could be helpful, and overall more time would also be helpful as lectures felt very busy with a lot of material covered.
As a 5 week course, this class obviously had a lot of information and it was taught it a very approachable way.

I think the large final drug project that we worked on throughout the entire course was a massive strength for the course. I think there should be more opportunities for extra help and office hours to better absorb the knowledge in this course.

This course provides students with not only the well-structured biochemistry course but the hands-on experiment to solidify students' knowledge. Besides from this, professor Collins provides office meeting hour by appointment, which could further the learning experience for students beyond the classroom.
Little suggestion: the direction for drug design activity would be more helpful if it provides a detailed example images of each procedure.

I think the course was a bit poorly planned. The first half went by very slowly and was just review. The latter half of the course had so much material crammed. There was literally three times as much reading as there was in the first half.
Great course, well-taught, packed with information. Make sure you have the time for this course.
Strength was Professor Collins, who singlehandedly carried the whole course and catered to all our academic needs. Does not need improvement.

Professor Collins is a fantastic lecturer and you can tell how much he cares about each of the students. I can't recommend this course enough, especially after having had generally negative experiences with other premed courses at Yale. Taking this class during the summer was a great call, because the class size was only 30 people we could ask questions, attend 1:1 office hours, etc. Professor Collins managed to make the virtual format engaging, organized, and effective for my learning.
The course abs lectures were structured well ! Homework assignments were at times a bit confusing but definitely manageable
This course was really good considering the nature of teaching online. The drug design project was very cool and the exams were fair with good feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I'm so glad I took biochemistry over the summer because I could take the time to focus on this course and understand the underlying concepts.
Yes! Definitely take this course if you are looking for a nice intro to key biochemical processes and concepts. I took it over the summer, and I felt like I learned a lot about biochemistry.
Yes - it is by far one of the better STEM classes (and especially pre-med classes) I've taken at yale. The small class size is so helpful and Prof. Collins is great.

Yes, if it is a requirement or if you are just interested in Biochemistry it is a lot of material to cover but it is very interesting and feels much more productive than organic chemistry because there is more learning and understanding, along with a greater degree of applicability of what is learned.
Yes I would, I like the succinctness of the syllabus within the 5 week period. I also enjoy the course very much which was a major factor in my evaluation.

YES! This course is really really rewarding! I would recommend with no reserve; this course is for every students that want to enhance their knowledge on biochemistry, and to get a hands-on project to solidify the concepts learned from the course.
Yes, it is necessary for understanding the basics of life science.
Absolutely, if Collins is teaching it! He's a great teacher and incredibly kind and flexible during the pandemic.
Absolutely. I took half a term of biochemistry at Yale before dropping it and Professor Collin's class was better by a long shot.
Yes. It presents the Biochemistry topics clearly and in-depth despite being a summer course.

Absolutely. Professor Collins is a fantastic lecturer and you can tell how much he cares about each of the students. I can't recommend this course enough, especially after having had generally negative experiences with other premed courses at Yale. Taking this class during the summer was a great call, because the class size was only 30 people we could ask questions, attend 1:1 office hours, etc. Professor Collins managed to make the virtual format engaging, organized, and effective for my learning.
Yes! Definitely take this course if you are interested in biochem or need it as a prerequisite
Yes - the professor is great and you learn a lot thats useful for the MCAT.
